justification: “The present study aimed to test this using a brief gamified smartphone task called ‘Meta Mind’, designed to measure metacognitive bias reliably, remotely, and in as few trials as possible.”

“A sunflower-themed visuo-perceptual decision-making task was used as the traditional metacognition task … Comparing the tasks, Meta Mind was relatively shorter … Metacognitive bias in Meta Mind… was significantly higher than in the traditional task.”

measured_by: M-Ratio metric (ratio of metacognitive sensitivity to accuracy)
justification: “In addition to metacognitive bias, we also quantified metacognitive efficiency via M-Ratio (i.e., the ratio of metacognitive sensitivity to mean accuracy, where sensitivity is the extent to which confidence ratings discriminate between correct and incorrect trials).”

measured_by: Round-level accuracy ratings in Meta Mind
justification: “After 20 trials, players evaluate their overall accuracy on that round, forming a ‘global’ self-performance evaluation based on round performance.”

measured_by: Composite score from 49 self-report items weighted by regularised regression model
justification: “Individual scores on dimensions of anxious-depression … were calculated by multiplying each of the 49 individual questionnaire responses by the corresponding weights from a previously published regularised regression model.”
